description: I'm personally pretty happy with this application. Has basic functionality, works well with OTP and I'm using it also on my Linux phone.
summary: Take care of your credentials, passwords and secrets, great app!

description:
For years I've used KeepassXC on Mac & Linux plus Keepass2Android, synced with Dropbox.

KeypassXC has a ton of features, but stuff like shortcut keys and browser integration have suffered seemingly because X and GNOME+Wayland are drifting apart.

Secrets looks nice, like it should be a default GNOME app and is promising for shedding the legacy cruft that KeepassXC has. BUT a password manager needs to be stable and useful for my workflow. The clipboard works (unlike KeepassXC in my Fedora Silverblue install), but there doesn't seem to be any keyboard shortcuts. Maybe browser integration and shortcuts will come later.

I just had to stop using it because of crashes. With some entries, just clicking on them would cause the app to crash. 

I like to see myself using Secrets some day in the future; I think it could perfectly integrate with a GNOME desktop. But a password manager *must* be stable with a standard feature set for me to use it every day.

I've used this program for about a year. It's served me well. It's rock solid, provides all the features I need, and is designed beautifully. I chose to use a password manager which uses the keepass format with syncthing syncing my encrypted passwords between my devices. So far I've found this to be a beautiful solution for password management.

Secrets did almost everything I wanted, and then surprised me when I found that it supported TOTP without fanfare. If there is one additional feature that would be useful for me, it would be temporary change history. Sometimes I try to close the program and get a "close without saving?" dialog, but can't remember if or what I changed. If there were a session changes history, that would help me be sure that I'm not losing data when I save or don't save after some unknown changes are made.

In short, this is a great password manager.
summary: This is a great password manager

description: Works great on PinePhone and support OTP.

I really like this app due to it being written with libadwaita and looking great on Gnome, therefor! As for improvements I would recommend some keyboard shortcuts to copy username and password and a credential autotype like the one in KeepassXC.

Love this app!

The app is very useful, simple to use, and very intuitive. 

I appreciate the app developer's hard work they have put into this app: thank you for doing what you do. Keep up the amazing work.
Simple and easy app to manage your passwords. But unfortunately, it shuts down suddenly right after introducing my master password.
summary: Nice interface with well GTK4 integrated in the new GTK4

description:
I have been using 1Password for quite a long time. However, I recently just went ahead and moved almost everything to free (as in freedom) software, and according to the privacy guide that I looked at (Techlore), they recommened KeePassXC. 

Secrets is a better frontend, and I love it, as it makes everything consistent with your desktop, while still having all of the awesomeness of KeePassXC. The best part is that it's a native GNOME app with all of the latest stuff. I would recommend it to anyone as it can be really versatile with syncing (via GNOME Online Accounts) and backups.
summary: The versatility of KeePassXC combined with the goodnesss of GNOME

description: It syncs with my KeePass android client, and I can even host my Safe file on my own server. It's really easy to create a new entry. App with great design and user experience!
summary: It's a great experience to use the app

description: Exactly what I wanted to see on my GNOME desk. Great!

only thing is adwaita dark theme setting seems to be ignored it worked with the deb package but not the flatpak


fcc

The UI is nice and clean (much more so than KeePass). I like the fact that you can create groups as well. It has potential to be a great manager. It would be nice if we could use both keyfiles and passwords to access a vault. It appears that this is intended but I don't think it's working right as when I add a keyfile it doesn't give me an option to apply settings.

Another thing is a lack of a save or create button when you create an entry or group. You instead have to assume that's it's been created and click back. So there needs to be at least a Done button as that is usually the more natural flow.
It's using libadwaita and is nicely designed I like the icon customizations.
summary: Well designed, seems to be secure

description: This application randomly changes from 'Secrets' to 'Password Safe' without warning. With either or both applications breaking. Why should I trust this behaviour when 'keepassxc' exists?
summary: This application randomly changes from 'Secrets' to 'Password Safe'

description: No crash, errors. Everything works fine. And have nice interface
I use Bitwarden as my main password manager but wanted a offline solution as well and Secrets works perfect! Nice clean ui and has worked on several different distros for me without issues!
summary: Awesome password safe, I would recommend!

description:
Have left an issue report. Have been having lag issues, particularly when typing. As soon as I start typing quicker than 1 word a second, the app can't keep up with the input, and the letters almost always appear in the inccorrect order. Not sure if it's something on my end but I may need to switch to XC for the time being as this is causing major inconvience. Other than that I like the app.

P.S. Response to jms on 17 Oct 2022: I don't see why you have a problem with the author renaming the application, as far as I'm aware this isn't shady behaviour. Even FOSS needs to consider market appeal when developing their products. The author has no obligation to keep you up to date, but hey maybe if you're nice and just ask then they'll be willing to help you out.

This is a really promising native password manager for GNOME. It's compatible with the latest KeePass file format, so all your data is encrypted and easily portable, and includes all the basic functionality you would expect (unlocking your database, adding entries, copying passwords, etc.).

For this to be an application I rely on daily, it just needs a few missing features. Specifically, I need to be able to view 2FA codes more quickly and easily copy them without having to dive into the entry properties first. I would also love for it to be able to download favicons, and ideally, support fingprint unlocking (via fprint). 

Once these additional features are in, this app will be unbeatable; as it stands, it's still a really great GNOME app if you're needing just the essential password manager features.
Using Fedora, trying to start application but nothing happens... Useless...

i use Fedora GnuLinux 38 on GNOME
Practical and beautiful, safe and modern
It is a bit slow when running
Please add other widgets like photo for encryption
Thanks
Looks great, has all the functionality needed
This is a great app and I hope it gets to have custom icon and the ability to download and use the website's icon like KeePassXC. I'm only using this because I use GNOME.

It wasn't working for me so I left negative score and I don't know how to remove it. Now it's working. It looks realy minimalistic and clearn but I have a feeling it's missing a lot of features that I'm using in KeePassXC
When it works, this password manager is great, but I have to give it two stars because it crashes constantly. Unfortunate.

The interface is cute but not practical for someone that has hundreds of passwords. 

I don't know if this has browser integration but that would be nice to have.
summary: Great design but not for heavy user

description: Ich fand die Applikation schon zuvor schon wirklich gut. Jetzt ist sie noch besser geworden.
Nothing for browser support, not showing icons (imported kdbx file), ui is not fast to navigate. Just don't like it. Prefer keepassxc

In my opinion Secrets is great, it looks realy nice and offers all the necessary features, but I have the problem that the app crashes as soon as I try to open an entry in my database that I created on my smartphone (synced with Syncthing), vice versa it works.
Einfache Passwortverwaltung mit minimalem Design, ist jedoch RAM-intensiver als vergleichbare Apps wie KeePassXC
Perfecto para almacenar tus contraseñas de forma local

Lo único que le falta para que la reemplace por KeepassXC es que tiene un soporte muy limitado de claves temporales TOTP. En varios casos simplemente no la genera y se limita a mostrar la semilla de la clave o la configuración. Parece que esto está determinado por el número de caracteres de la semilla.
summary: Excelente integración con GNOME pero todavía le falta desarrollo
